topic.title: Scenario for threat model.
topic.body:
Hi all,

I would appreciate your constructive feedback on a scenario for a threat model. The aim is to test communication apps. But there are so many of them available, that it’s difficult to weed out which ones shall be used and which ones shall be avoided. So to decide on the specifications sheet, it’s easier to have a not-so-fictitious scenario that is used to benchmark the features of the app, what we’re looking for and also to help prioritise features by order of importance. This app would be used in a business environment, so users are not necessarily supposed to be geeks. And it’s not used to send messages to girlfriends/boyfriends either, it can have devastating implications if communication is falling in the wrong hands. So we need to find an app that ticks the OpSec boxes for real life use in a complicated environment. The aim of having a scenario is to help make discussions more down to earth, instead of ending up with the one shouting the louder winning the argument.

This thread is not about getting opinions on apps or devices to use. This thread is only about deciding on a scenario. Then, and only once we have a consensus on a relevant scenario, can we start reviewing apps and devices, one at a time. And these reviews would be made according to the scenario, not according to each and any specific case of the reviewer (that's you and me). So basically, this scenario is a way to structure the review and not make it personal.

So here is the scenario:

We are a news agency, such as "The Guardian". Our team of journalists were investigating international drug cartels, when they realise corruption was occurring as deep as prosecutors, law enforcement and customs clearance officers, the military and many administrative clerks. They realise corruption was also happening in self proclaimed "democracies" and self proclaimed "developed countries" such as France, the UK or the US.

Our journalists knew for a fact that they could be arrested and jailed, indefinitely, without any charges whatsoever. They knew for a fact that their homes could be invaded, their property stolen, their family harassed or physically harmed, without any possibility of using the law to defend themselves.
They knew for a fact that surveillance tools would be used against them, their collaborators, their sources, their families.

So the news agency decided to be proactive in protecting its journalists and sources. Instead of the naive "if I have nothing to hide then I have nothing to fear", or sometimes "if I'm not doing anything illegal then I have nothing to fear" which is constantly proving to be a false and dangerous approach, the news agency decided to protect all communications and data, at all time, no matter their perceived importance. And to protect all the people they were in contact with, including families, suppliers, contractors, sources and so on.

Because the threat was not about what they were actually doing, or with whom. The threat when dealing with state-sponsored criminals is: what kind of false and baseless accusations can they invent in order to cause harm to the organisation, under the colour of law.

In this scenario, if you replace "drug cartels" with "political parties" or "surveillance agencies" or "weapon dealers" or "pharmaceutical companies" or "crude oil company" you'll see that the threat remains the same.

State-sponsored criminals can harm individuals, businesses, non-profit organisations, for no other reason than to satisfy their urge of domination and social status. And to mimic what they see on television with all their electronic devices and firearms. They get their kick of dopamine by destroying lives and projects. They are out of control, without any real supervision, there is no such thing as check and balance when it comes to state-sponsored criminals.

One could end up fighting the justice system for years, spending its entire income, just to dismiss false and baseless accusations from a brain dead police officer or a sadistic prosecutor.

We live in a world where those who are doing nothing wrong but just want to live a peaceful life and run a successful business must protect themselves against the most evil form of criminality.

OpSec is not backward compatible. You protect yourself from state-sponsored criminals before they can even come to know about you and your business.

Yes, but again, you're steering the discussion away from the subject. We're not talking backups here, but decentralization. If their is a single point of failure, then it's not decentralized. Whether the user(s) opt for Matrix (federated) or Signal (US centralized open source) or Telegram (global citizen centralized closed source with multiple servers) is based on the threat model. For Telegram, the biggest threat seems to be state-sponsored criminals (aka governments) so they have servers in many countries, which are as many "jurisdictions" in legal terms. For Signal, it seems they still think US is a state of law (it's a criminal state to the highest order), so for them being open source in the US does the trick. Matrix is another culture, a culture of developers, they are good at programming but utopians.

We had a matrix server for our organization. It got hacked and taken down (by Chinese it seems, maybe just fooling around). So then, because it takes a lot of time to manage such a server, we moved to their servers and set up other instances for our organization. But we learned our lesson. We use other apps so secure our communications and as fail over. Jami and Briar are ones of a few to be really decentralized. The problem with Jami is that you don't have offline messaging (yet). Wickr is the only one with a true self-destroy feature that wipes the messages in a manner that makes them unrecoverable, even (apparently) using Cellebrite (Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QGymjCi6khI) (Article 1: https://www.wired.com/story/smartphone-encryption-law-enforcement-tools/) (Article 2: https://www.wired.com/story/cellebrite-ufed-ios-12-iphone-hack-android/).

But again, we're steering to other topics, which are the threat model and the recoverability of deleted messages.

Initially the thread is about Signal And Telegram. Which offer very few benefits actually, compared to Wire, Wickr, Threema, Jami, Briar and so on.

And my post about Matrix was just to point out that it is not decentralized, but federated, like Diaspora and Mastodon. So if people are after resiliency, they should put decentralization first in their specifications sheet.

> [binary1173](#comment_57_17MrYppaLZw5RG3iKFSp4JhL3gMznVgB1G): Everyone is entitled to chose what they want in the realms of security/privacy, the discussion is about these two which personally I would not/do not use. Bottom line if you want to use these go ahead, but with so many better offerings out there, its short sighted to assume these two 'main stream top 10' will mitigate the risk posed just because everyone else is getting on the band wagon because all it does is move the goal posts into another barrel that Govt can attack or surpress.

I agree. I wouldn't use either Signal nor Telegram for personal or business purpose.
Telegram, maybe to host a public channel/group if you think you're going to have a lot of followers. But then, you're absolutely not after privacy, it's just used as a contender to Discord.
Someone coming to me, asking if (s)he shall use Signal or Telegram, I would answer Threema, Wire, Wickr, Briar, Jami and as you said there are so many apps available. Note that if you send them to Matrix/Element, there is some explaining to do. For one, it's not encrypted by default, you have to create an encrypted chat room (Telegram isn't encrypted by default either). Then, the keys are created for each device, so (for now), you can't move your account to another device without moving the keys at the same time. It's not difficult for geeks, but for people new to encryption, it might be just a little above their proficiency level. Hence the explaining to do.
It's good to see that on Zeronet there are people who contribute experience and knowledge on these topics.
What about we test apps together? I've seen someone giving his Briar key, I think I'll give it a try to review this app by myself.

> [sword000000](#comment_94_114FPBgGTFgsfrHMvQYkJ3aAR8zSmbyjie): It appears you are confusing "Decentralized" with P2P. Even in the link you posted, Matrix is listed as a decentralized network. Yes, Matrix is Federated. P2P and Federated are Both types of decentralized networks. I'm sorry to hear about your group server being attacked and taken offline. While your server was compromised, the rest of the Matrix network continued to function. Matrix uses Federated decentralization.

I see where this is going.

Matrix would be decentralised if data from your own server was copied to other servers and ready to be used as fail over. Decentralisation is the process of having your data spread across instances. For physical items, it would be to keep every single item composing your stock held in many warehouses instead of all of it in one big warehouse which is the way to go so as to rationalise costs, so you pay to mitigate risk of loss. The military is decentralised. 

Federation barely allows clients from the bar next door to get a free pass to the night club if so they wish. It's more like being in the same yellow pages. I see it at the step forward after the highly centralised apps we were fed with, like Facebook. But compared to truly decentralised apps, there isn't much substance to it. Matrix could become decentralised.

p2p is decentralising the communication channels only, not the data. In the case of Briar for example, it's p2p, but if the device hosting the forum goes offline or is destroyed, then the data is gone forever and for everyone.

Blockchain is decentralised because each node/miner has an entire copy of the data, although it doesn't mean it can access it as it can be encrypted, it only means it has a copy available. There are a few blockchain projects that aim to offer decentralised storage, like Storj. In the case of Matrix, if a few other servers in the federation circle were holding encrypted copies of your data, and these copies would instantly become available in case of your main server going down, then yes it would be decentralised. Federated systems are not resilient and are expensive to maintain. I'm not sure Diaspora and Mastodon are going to live long with all these social media apps using the blockchain.

There is no need to use blockchain to be decentralised. There is no need to be p2p to be decentralised.
Retroshare is decentralised: https://retroshare.cc
Manyverse is decentralised: https://www.manyver.se

Zeronet is decentralised AND p2p. Best of both worlds (and anonymous). Zeronet has a social media component that works well (ZeroMe). It's just the websites that currently are a bit difficult for non programmers to build, because they don't have a wordpress like CRM. And you can't manage access rights, ike giving editor access while retaining administrator access. With Steemit (blockchain) you can give the editing key while keeping the owner key.

I'm not going into decentralised vs distributed. Or we open an other thread if you're interested in the topic. You can find more about it by reading the whitepaper of Ubinodes: https://cp.sync.com/dl/6c98c4050/j7fpiw84-gcikx899-7vzzx448-3nb5b6y9

This thread was about Signal vs Telegram, it seems that here the consensus is to not use any of them and go for other alternatives. Maybe we could open threads to discuss other apps? One at a time.

> [qzm](#comment_21_1HyrFrFXUHZC58qLuFrjAXm2Jjkb3Y6ufX): If we want to talk about a scenario in which operational security could become important on a day-to-day basis, I don’t think that being a political dissident in 2021 is too far off from the mark.The federal government has all but branded everyone on the right as terrorists, and I think that we can expect action to be taken slowly over the period of the next few years against individuals who fall into that category. We saw it with the weaponization of the IRS under the Obama administration, and they think that we will see similar action taken against disagreeing types during this administration.OPSEC is not something that can be maintained by people who are not diligent, adequately fearful, and motivated to do so. Given this, I recommend not putting every single individual within your organization on some kind of secure chat application or secure email server in which they are to conduct all of their business all the time. The danger in this is simple, do you really want your local law-enforcement to wonder why all of your communications are encrypted, or otherwise hidden? I think that it would be better to identify those activities which should remain hidden from law-enforcement, regulators, or business enemies, and ensure that all communications pertaining to those activities are secure. Think about it, a small number of elements makes for a simple and easy to control system. A few individuals can be trained to maintain operational security and it is easier to ensure that they are doing so then it is to haphazardly train a large number of individuals and then attempt to keep them accountable.If I were to establish a secure channel of communication, you can bet your bottom dollar that no one who has not been properly trained and vetted would ever be permitted to access it.So my advice is regardless of the threat scenario keep your system small, and simple. Train a few people, only those who have critical need for security. If you absolutely must have everybody on a secure system then ensure that those critical actors are on a separate system then the larger mass of people who need lower security.
